channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Body parts found in Becky search
item.description: Police investigating the disappearance of Bristol teenager Becky Watts find body parts.

item.title: Jail threat for sex abuse 'neglect'
item.description: Teachers, councillors and social workers in England and Wales who fail to protect children from sexual exploitation could face up to five years in jail under proposals being unveiled by the PM.

item.title: Emwazi tape: I'm no extremist
item.description: A recording emerges in which the Islamic State fighter Mohammed Emwazi, known as "Jihadi John", denied being an extremist and said MI5 threatened him.

item.title: Russia restricts Nemtsov mourners
item.description: Several EU politicians and Russia's opposition leader are barred from attending the funeral of murdered Russian opposition politician Boris Nemtsov.

item.title: Rise in reports of discrimination
item.description: Incidents of discrimination in English professional and grassroots football has increased, according to Kick It Out.

item.title: Barclays annual profits fall 21%
item.description: Barclays reports a 21% fall in full-year statutory pre-tax profits, as boss Antony Jenkins is awarded his first bonus as chief executive.

item.title: Two questioned over missing Becky
item.description: Police investigating the disappearance of Bristol teenager Becky Watts continue to question two people, arrested on suspicion of murder.

item.title: Obama seeks long Iran nuclear freeze
item.description: The US president says Iran should freeze nuclear activity for 10 years, ahead of a controversial Washington speech by Israel's prime minister.

item.title: Baby deaths inquiry report due
item.description: Failures at a maternity unit where a number of newborn babies and mothers died are expected to be exposed later.

item.title: Sturgeon: Equality key to prosperity
item.description: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is to highlight new economic analysis to say tackling inequality will lead to greater prosperity.

item.title: Property offences 'decriminalised'
item.description: Theft, burglary and shoplifting have "virtually been decriminalised" because the offences are not treated as a priority by police or the courts, a report for a think tank suggests.

item.title: Ex-Spurs midfielder Mackay dies
item.description: Former Tottenham, Derby, Hearts and Scotland midfielder Dave Mackay dies, aged 80.

item.title: Johnson arrest, abuse law and a paracetamol 'alert'
item.description: The arrest of footballer Adam Johnson, new abuse laws, and a safety warning over paracetamol are all topics in Tuesday's newspapers.

item.title: Netanyahu's speech 'win-win' for Iran
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's speech to Congress is a strategic moment for Tehran, says the BBC's Jonathan Marcus.

item.title: Will Sony march away from mobile?
item.description: Rory Cellan-Jones meets the chief executive of Sony and wonders if it is time the firm should prepare for an exit from the smartphone market.

item.title: Can regional force defeat Boko Haram?
item.description: Thomas Fessy looks at whether the regional task force has a fighting chance against Nigeria's Boko Haram militant group.

item.title: Can the UK afford to defend itself?
item.description: What measures will be needed for the UK to meet Nato targets for defence, writes Prof Malcolm Chalmers, of security think tank the Royal United Services Institute.

item.title: What next for Russia's opposition?
item.description: It is time for the Kremlin's opponents to stop jostling for primacy and let the Russian people take the lead, writes Konstantin von Eggert.

item.title: VIDEO: How strong is Iraq's army?
item.description: Iraq's army is battling an jihadist insurgency - but how strong is the force?

item.title: Does Australia need foreign investment?
item.description: Foreign land ownership is seen by many as a problem in Australia but the farm sector has another side to the story.

item.title: Tinder to charge over-28s more
item.description: Dating app Tinder announces it will charge the over-28s nearly four times as much for its premium features as it does younger users in the UK.

item.title: Road tunnel turned into nightclub
item.description: A tunnel on Coventry's notorious ring road is to be transformed into a nightclub as part of a three-day motoring festival.

item.title: FA wants Team GB sides at Rio 2016
item.description: The Football Association is planning to enter men's and women's Great Britain teams at the Rio 2016 Olympic Games.

item.title: England footballer in sex arrest
item.description: England and Sunderland footballer Adam Johnson is arrested and bailed on suspicion of sexual activity with a 15-year-old girl.

item.title: Should England expect to win Slams?
item.description: After hopes of a Six Nations clean sweep slip by for another year, Tom Fordyce asks whether English rugby fans should expect more.

item.title: Terry hopeful over new Chelsea deal
item.description: Chelsea captain John Terry says he is keen to have "a few years" more at the club, but would not leave to play elsewhere.

item.title: Singapore 'world's priciest city'
item.description: For the second year running, Singapore tops the list as the world's most expensive city to live in, says the Economist Intelligence Unit.

item.title: Bill Gates tops Forbes rich list
item.description: Bill Gates is declared the richest man in the world for the 16th time by Forbes magazine's annual ranking of global billionaires.

item.title: Parliament may be abandoned - Bercow
item.description: The Houses of Parliament could have to be "abandoned" within 20 years without extensive repair work, Commons Speaker John Bercow says.

item.title: Security strategy 'will be rushed'
item.description: The UK's next national security strategy will be prepared in an "unnecessary rush", a committee of MPs and peers says.

item.title: Coffee linked to 'cleaner' arteries
item.description: Drinking a few cups of coffee a day may help people avoid clogged arteries - a known risk factor for heart disease - South Korean researchers believe.

item.title: Child health 'an election issue'
item.description: Measures to protect children's health should be put at the forefront of the general election, say doctors.

item.title: Children's homes 'lack secure places'
item.description: Local authorities are struggling to house some of the most disturbed children because of a shortage of places in secure children's homes.

item.title: One-third miss school choice in London
item.description: Almost a third of families in London did not get their first choice of secondary school as the population surge reaches secondary level.

item.title: Samsung S6 phone has curved screen
item.description: Samsung confirms that one version of its new Galaxy S6 flagship smartphone will have a screen that curves round its sides

item.title: Ikea debuts phone-charging furniture
item.description: Furniture giant Ikea has unveiled a range of furniture fitted with wireless charging spots for mobile devices.

item.title: Rosetta catches its own shadow
item.description: The Rosetta satellite sees its own shadow in the highest resolution image it has so far taken of Comet 67P.

item.title: Bright spotlight on Ceres mission
item.description: As Nasa's Dawn satellite prepares to enter into orbit around the dwarf planet Ceres, scientists say they are excited to learn more about the two bright spots on its surface.

item.title: Phoenix Nights star thanks medics
item.description: Comedian Ted Robbins says he is lucky to be alive after his collapse during a stage show.

item.title: Craig films Comic Relief Bond sketch
item.description: Bond star Daniel Craig will appear as 007 in a Comic Relief sketch to air on Red Nose Day, Friday 13 March.

item.title: What would Wittgenstein say about that dress?
item.description: The colour of "that dress" has been fascinating people all around the world, including Prof Barry C Smith of the University of London's Institute of Philosophy.

item.title: Weekend edition: The best of the week's reads
item.description: A collection of some of the best reads from the BBC News website this week.

item.title: 'No hiding' from abuse failures
item.description: There is "no hiding" from the failures of authorities in Oxfordshire where young girls were groomed, a retired detective tells the BBC.

item.title: Unsafe fridges 'risk lives' warning
item.description: Lives are being put at risk by fires fuelled by fridge freezers insulated with flammable materials, says London Fire Brigade.

item.title: A&E waiting time targets missed
item.description: Scotland's A&E departments treated 87% of people within the Scottish government's target of four hours in January, NHS statistics show.

item.title: Snow closes schools and hits travel
item.description: Heavy snow falls close a small number of schools and affects driving conditions in parts of Scotland.

item.title: Audit office critical of IT scheme
item.description: An IT company was awarded a 1.3m euros (£950,000) grant to buy equipment which "in all likelihood" cost it 30,000 euros (£22,000), the NI Audit Office concludes.

item.title: DPP to get supergrass claims file
item.description: The Police Ombudsman is to send a file to the director of public prosecutions this month for him to decide if two former police officers should be prosecuted for a range of crimes, including conspiracy to murder.

item.title: Vote to be held on smacking ban
item.description: AMs will vote on Tuesday on whether or not to ban smacking children.

item.title: Drugs ban rugby player sold steroids
item.description: A former rugby player continued to produce and supply anabolic steroids after being banned from the sport for trafficking, a BBC Wales investigation reveals.

item.title: $80m for Sierra Leone to fight Ebola
item.description: The International Monetary Fund says Sierra Leone is to receive more than $80m (£52m) immediately to help the country overcome the Ebola outbreak.

item.title: Namibia president wins $5m award
item.description: Outgoing Namibian President Hifikepunye Pohamba wins the world's most valuable individual award, the Mo Ibrahim prize for African leadership.

item.title: Australia to bolster force in Iraq
item.description: Australia is to more than double its contingent of troops training local forces in Iraq, Prime Minister Tony Abbott says.

item.title: North Korea lifts Ebola travel ban
item.description: North Korea will once again allow tourists into the country after four months of severe restrictions to prevent the spread of Ebola.

item.title: 'Monitoring deal' on Ukraine truce
item.description: Ukrainian, Russian, French and German leaders agree to send observers to areas of Ukraine where truce violations are reported, Kiev says.

item.title: France 'rebuked over smacking'
item.description: Europe's top rights watchdog is set to rule that France's guidance over spanking children is not sufficiently clear, Le Monde newspaper reports.

item.title: US told to cut 80 Caracas diplomats
item.description: Venezuela orders the United States to cut more than 80 staff from its diplomatic mission in the next two weeks.

item.title: Uruguay leaders' love of old cars
item.description: Newly inaugurated Uruguayan president Tabare Vazquez continues his predecessor Jose Mujica's tradition of using vintage cars for official engagements.

item.title: Iraq 'seizes districts from IS'
item.description: Iraqi forces say they have retaken some districts around Tikrit in their fight to recapture the strategic city from Islamic State.

item.title: Libya names Haftar as army chief
item.description: Libya's internationally recognised government in Tobruk names former controversial anti-Islamist Khalifa Haftar as the new head of the national army.

item.title: Homeless man 'reached for LAPD gun'
item.description: The Los Angeles police chief says a homeless man shot dead by police had reached for an officer's weapon before being killed.

item.title: 'Cloudy' drug halts US execution
item.description: The execution of the first woman in Georgia in 70 years is postponed because the drug that was to be used appeared "cloudy", US officials say.

item.title: Day in pictures: 2 March 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 2 March

item.title: Leonard 'Spock' Nimoy: Life in pictures
item.description: Leonard 'Spock' Nimoy has died

item.title: Week in pictures: 21-27 February 2015
item.description: News photos from around the world

item.title: Halfway in 24-year photo project
item.description: Photographers recording the first 24 hours of each year

item.title: Day in pictures: 27 February 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 27 February

item.title: Your pictures: Gardens
item.description: Readers' photographs on the theme of gardens

item.title: Brit Awards 2015: In Pictures
item.description: Highlights from this year's ceremony in London

item.title: In pictures: Vintage Nasa photographs for sale
item.description: Space photos go under the hammer

item.title: VIDEO: Treasury Committee
item.description: MPs are taking evidence on the Bank of England Foreign Exchange Market Investigation.

item.title: VIDEO: Skydiver saved after mid-air seizure
item.description: A quick-thinking skydiving instructor in Western Australia came to the rescue when one of his students had an epileptic seizure during a jump.

item.title: VIDEO: Why life in Singapore is so expensive
item.description: Singapore is the world's most expensive city, according to an index compiled by the Economist Intelligence Unit.

item.title: VIDEO: Emwazi audio recording emerges
item.description: A recording has emerged in which the Islamic State fighter Mohammed Emwazi denied being an extremist and complained about UK security services.

item.title: VIDEO: Spy inside al-Qaeda goes public
item.description: An agent who infiltrated al-Qaeda on behalf of British intelligence has spoken to the BBC for the first time, the BBC's Gordon Corera reports.

item.title: VIDEO: Detained plane spotters 'knew rules'
item.description: The relatives of three British men who say they were arrested while plane spotting in Dubai have spoken to BBC Breakfast.

item.title: VIDEO: Sensors everywhere: MWC's new gadgets
item.description: The Mobile World Congress is taking place in Barcelona and it features a wide array of products connected by mobile technology.

item.title: VIDEO: WW1 ship given new lease of life
item.description: A century after battering enemy positions in World War One, the only surviving British ship from the Gallipoli campaign, the HMS M33, is being given a new lease of life.

item.title: VIDEO: 'How I was radicalised online'
item.description: 'Ayesha', not her real name, was once a radical Muslim who found the lifestyle, initially, "glamorous" and attractive.

item.title: Delhi rapist says victim shouldn't have fought back
item.description: Delhi bus rapist says victim shouldn't have fought back

item.title: The spy who came in from al-Qaeda
item.description: The founder member of al-Qaeda who worked for MI6

item.title: The art of before-and-after pictures
item.description: Just how reliable are 'before and after' photos?

item.title: What people see instead of darkness
item.description: What do you see when you close your eyes?

item.title: Been and Gone: Champion F1 designer and Janis Joplin's guitarist
item.description: A champion F1 designer and other notable losses

item.title: Who killed Boris Nemtsov?
item.description: Theories abound over murder that shocked Moscow

item.title: VIDEO: The art rescued from Nazi looters
item.description: The 50-year fight to recover paintings looted by the Nazis

item.title: Yemen crisis: 'Living in despair'
item.description: A mechanic, a merchant and an artist tell of struggle in Yemen
